summary: This is an email exchange discussing an 11th Circuit Court decision (In re Wild) which held that rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act do not attach until formal criminal proceedings are initiated, and thus were not triggered in the Jeffrey Epstein case because the government entered into a non-prosecution agreement without filing charges. The email forwards a legal analysis of this ruling.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the non-prosecution agreement and the failed prosecution referenced in the 11th Circuit case discussed in the email.

events.title: 11th Circuit Decision in In re Wild
events.description: The 11th Circuit Court of Appeals decided that rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) do not attach until criminal proceedings are formally initiated (by complaint, information, or indictment). The court applied this to the Epstein case, finding the CVRA was never triggered because the government entered into a non-prosecution agreement without filing charges.

keyFacts: The 11th Circuit Court ruled in In re Wild that Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) rights only attach after formal criminal proceedings begin.
The ruling specifically addressed the Epstein case, stating the CVRA was never triggered because the government never filed charges against Epstein.
The government's action was entering into a non-prosecution agreement with Epstein instead of initiating criminal proceedings.
